Yes! Something similar to how PUBG, Sky, Bullet League, and all these other games that have more innovative touch controls suited for action and dynamic 3D movement. A dynamic system where the left side controls movement with a joystick that jumps to wherever you touch in that area, and the right side controls looking and aiming and mining, and the jump button, crouch, and run buttons could be on that side by default too. If you allow us to move and resize the buttons, and scale the buttons and the hitboxes of the buttons independently, to compensate for screen real-estate vs usability, the game would feel much more natural to control (Bullet League does this, for an example).

Running could be done by having a "Run" button above the joystick that you have to swipe up to, mimicking the pressing down of an analog stick.

This decade of mobile gaming has really raised the bar for touchscreen control standards, allowing the controls to adapt to you and compensate for a lack of tactile feedback. Lots of inspiration in the other games out there to draw on.

The colours for the mobs would be so its easier for me and other hard of hearing/deaf players would be able to recognise what's happening, with it being the same colour as some unwanted information its really hard to pay attention to what's going on ^^

This would be so helpful especially when caving, course I ain't going to see a single 'creeper hisses' when the subtitles reach to the top of my screen, but ill see a bright cyan or magenta and know to get the hell out of dodge. Especially agree with the ability to turn off some subtitles, or being able to turn off 'block breaking, block broken, block placed and footsteps' for your own player cause its really unnecessary as the visual information for that is happening right behind the cursor i.e. where your looking like 75% of the time.

Hi there Coda! I absolutely love this idea of colored mob tags in the subtitles section of the game, I often find myself struggling to read the stack of text to find the mob names and while simultaneously trying to pay attention to the screen! I'm sure you can relate when I say how stressful and scary this is on hardcore worlds and I think this change would be an easy, yet effective solution to that problem! :)
I'm not deaf, but I have sensitive hearing so like having most sounds turned off, I agree that MC could use better subtitles.
Yes please

What do think about that idea:
Instead of adding a new key binding, just modify the existing 'Pick-block' functionality a bit.

Clicking 'Pick-block' with a tool in the main hand (pickaxe, axe, shovel, hoe) will switch to the correct mining tool in the hotbar. If none available it gets swapped with a suitable tool from the inventory.

If you are already holding a suitable mining tool, circle through similar tool from the entire inventory. For instance use 'Pick-block' to switch between your Silk Touch and Fortune pickaxes.

Clicking 'Pick-block' with an empty hand or other item works as beforehand.

This ways our hotbar doesn't get filled with tools and we don't have to open the inventory so often.

Yes, please! I like that idea; it saves a lot of time. To make things easier, you could add a system for organizing your inventory by pressing "i" to open up your inventory, and then holding "i" for 3 seconds to  automatically organize your inventory via AI, using a number of factors. These factors include: category of items, durability, color, quantity, ect. players could also organize their hotbar by double-clicking the middle mouse button, which if it's the first time in that world, then it will "save" the hotbar so that the computer will remember it later when you go to organize it again. This is very useful for when you died and collected all your stuff, but the items are mixed up in your inventory. if you want to clear your saved hotbar, just hold Ctrl+middle mouse button.

I am looking forward to this suggestion, because players will automatically close the interface because of other players' attacks or biological attacks when making items or chatting, but it will also bring some troubles to players. For example, if you are attacked while chatting, the text in the chat bar will be automatically deleted, which will take more time for players to re-enter the text. Adding a switch can automatically close and disable each interface when it is hit.

Although the vertigo effect will bring immersive experience to players, it may cause discomfort to some players due to their physiological reasons, and they can't better judge the hell situation. You can add a button to turn this function on or off, which kills two birds with one stone.
A basic game feature that has been missing for too long.

Thank you for pointing out this valid and quite serious accessibility issue. It is clear that in a conflict between achievement gatekeeping and accessibility, the latter should prevail 1000%. It is simple to turn achievements back on after having used creative mode. Worlds can be downloaded to make getting them easy on any platform. For someone intentionally trying to cheat, it is trivial, but for someone requiring add-ons for accessibility, you cannot reenable achievements without also removing your add-ons. 

Minecraft for the most part allows players to choose how they play the game and what is important to them. Achievements add a sense of enjoyment and validation. It is shameful for this validation to be withheld for disabled people but not for cheaters.
